What can be done? State can negotiate health insurance rates for all their public school employees, as North Carolina does. When negotiating, prioritize transparency. Districts could also form consortia to help leverage their combined size and purchasing power. And, well, increase teacher pay. End 🧵

If we at home anticipate and prepare for the onslaught of germs at the start of each school year, imagine the predicament of teachers who spend approximately 7 hours daily in classrooms with our precious children. Would you choose to teach if you lacked a reliable health safety net?

A notable repercussion of the declining affordability of health insurance is the gradual decrease in health coverage take-up rates. Consider this: some of our teachers enter the classroom without the vital protection of health insurance.

The ⬆️cost of health insurance has also impacted school districts, leading some to reduce the % of health insurance premiums they cover. Some that covered 100% of health insurance premiums for employees + their families have been forced to discontinue this practice due to financial constraints.
The average annual cost of health insurance for a family of four is now over $20,000, of which public school employees pay an average of $8000.

According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, health insurance costs have increased by more than 80% since 2010. During the same period, average teacher salaries only increased by 23%, lower even than the general inflation rate.

My latest & last NCTQ blog post zooms in on the last 5 years of what's been happening w/the cost of health insurance for teachers, and shows how individual districts have responded.  www.nctq.org/blog/Affordi... 
But here's a short thread that takes a longer look at those trends 🧵

This is one of those that you go "but of course!", but that it's good to see scientific confirmation on.

Exciting News!
After careful consideration, I have decided to leave my role as Senior Economist at NCTQ at the end of February 2024. I will be looking for new opportunities to apply my quantitative, research, and analysis skills to education policy to drive positive change in an equitable way.

I was about to ask why are they called “digestives” - they look like regular crackers which, if you eat too many, tend to have the opposite effect, iykwim. You post tells me they are NOT regular crackers 😶

I’m making pizza dough with the discard, which I was going to make today anyways. But I still have lots more discard. How do you optimize your sourdough experience #EconSky?

Maybe it’s me, but I think that for an economist, sourdough is hard to embrace with all the “discard”. I’m looking for recipes that use the discard. But if it’s not something I’d planned on in the first place, it’s still suboptimal. Thoughts? Perspectives?
#EconSky #EconCooks

3. Report trends of the educator supply & demand variables, AND shortage projections. Responses to educator shortages have been more reactive than proactive. Adopting a forward-looking stance means policymakers responses are not just putting out fires but allows to plan more strategically.

2. Collect & publish educator supply & demand data, well disaggregated, as well as teacher prep outcomes. This is not only increases transparency that informs the public discourse, but also allows for surgical policy tools to address staffing challenges, rather than inch-deep mile-wide solutions.

1. Creation of a public job posting database. W/highly localized teacher labor markets, this type of centralized information can help induce mobility to mitigate geographical shortages. This also allows for real time information on vacancies to act on, rather than relying on lagged data.
Yesterday the state of Pennsylvania passed SB 843, which is a big step towards data-informed teacher workforce policies. Some salient points in the mandates of this bill:🧵

Districts have continued increasing pay and lowering requirements for subs, but maybe that’s not all they need to be concerned with. They ought to also be looking at subs' next best option, and that might very well be Walmart.

There is evidence of strategic behavior in how some districts offer sub pay. I've seen incentives for longevity (e.g. cash bonuses for subs who work>60 days/semester), less desirable days (e.g. higher pay for subs to teach on Fridays), subbing for special ed, or subbing at high poverty schools.
There IS, however, a general positive correlation between what districts require in order to substitute teach and what they pay them. Here’s what it looks like with education requirements.

Starting sub pay varies widely. In our sample, it goes from $10/hr to $42/hr (price parity adjusted). Typically subs don’t sub for a living, but as reference, 80% of those districts pay below MIT's "living wage". Here’s the link to the live graph if you want to see who’s who. tinyurl.com/nsewsem3

But some subs are more qualified, so they qualify for higher pay rates, *both* in education and in retail. Even for the highest sub pay offered (not including high-needs pay), in 35% of the districts in our sample they’d be better off working in a highly paid retail position.

I look at the pay offered by districts, not at the actual take up, because this is meant to inform policy. I find that 40% of the districts in our sample (of ~150 of the largest in the US) offer starting sub pay (the lowest rates, corresponding to the lowest requirements) below average retail pay.

👋🏽Me, again, looking at relative pay. 
Substitute shortages are among the most critical. In my newest blog I look at how sub pay compares to retail pay. Offering competitive wages is especially relevant in an economy where there’s tons of hiring. www.nctq.org/blog/Are-you...

Let's say your institution asks you to write something you disagree with, you
a) write it, they're paying you
b) write it & have it go w/o your name
c) write it w/o the part you disagree with, hand it over, they can do what they want with it
d) don't write it & face consequences
